awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: DNA Packing of Bacteriophages: Liquid Crystal Modeling through Analysis, Knot Theory  and Numerical Simulation.
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria and whose genome is,  in some cases,  a double stranded DNA molecule. In order to develop strains of double stranded (ds) DNA bacteriophages that can be efficiently used in nanotechnology and for treatment of bacterial infections, a detailed mathematical and biophysical characterization of the packing and delivery of the viral genome is required. Paradoxically, very little is known about these processes due to the extreme density and pressure conditions that the DNA is subject to inside the virus. In the proposed research, the investigators will combine experimental work and the theory of liquid crystals to determine the properties and organization of the DNA molecule inside bacteriophages and of its release. The project will establish a firm theoretical framework for genome delivery in nano-technological applications. In particular, it will produce the first analytical model describing the liquid crystalline phase of DNA in confinement. Two postdoctoral fellows and at least two graduate students will be trained each year. Results and materials will be broadly disseminated, through open access as well as standard journals and conference presentations. Materials developed in this project will be presented at the UC Davis program for high school students COSMOS. Collaborations and contacts with device development laboratories will be established.

The overarching hypothesis of the project is that the DNA molecule inside the viral capsid forms a hexagonal chromonic liquid crystal phase for which mathematical models are lacking. In the proposed project, the investigators will first build a mechanical model determined by an energy function that incorporates information from cryo-EM data, information from semiflexible polymers, results from Onsager theory of lyotropic liquid crystals and parameters from experiments on chromonic liquid crystals. Next, they will extend their mechanical model by including polyelectrolyte gel features, acknowledging the presence of water with many types of ions and their interaction with the negative charge of the DNA molecule. Third, the investigators will develop models of delivery of genomes with different biophysical properties. Furthermore, the investigators hypothesize that defects in the DNA liquid crystalline ordering are manifested as knots and DNA kinks. The proposed mathematical and computational models will be, both, guided and validated by multiple experimental techniques including cryo-EM, topological analysis, estimation of osmotic pressures and delivery of DNA sequences. The ultimate goal of this project is to construct and analyze a mathematical model of chromonic liquid crystals capable of making packing, pressure and delivery predictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The properties of the double stranded (ds)DNA molecule in free solution are well understood and accurate quantitative models have already been developed and analyzed by many researchers. Accurate descriptions of DNA under spatial confinement, however, remain mostly unexplored.

We chose the bacteriophage as a model system to study DNA under confinement because in most organisms, DNA wraps around histones or histone like proteins that obscure its biophysical properties. Bacteriophages are viruses that propagate in bacteria and package their DNA in a protein container called capsid and in the absence of other DNA binding structural proteins.

Although the overall mathematical expression of the energy of confined DNA molecules is mostly unknown, two factors are known to significantly contribute to the free energy of the system. Inside the capsid the DNA molecule is known to be in its liquid crystalline form due to the high local density of DNA fibers; under a very high bending stress due to the comparable size of the DNA persistence length in free solution and the capsid diameter (i.e. 45 nm); and under strong electrostatic repulsion due the negative charge and high local density of the DNA molecule.

In this project we have developed the mathematical framework to study DNA inside bacteriophage capsids using the theory of continuum mechanics of liquid crystals. We have implemented a mechanical model, both analytical and numerical, that takes into account DNA bending and incorporates the electrostatic repulsion as a mechanical expression with bulk and shear components. Our model is built on cryo-EM data that show that the DNA molecule inside the capsid is organized in coaxial spooling layers and a disordered core. Our model takes the diameter of the capsid and the length of the DNA as input and predicts the osmotic pressure and the size of the disordered core inside the capsid . Using this model we analytically showed that toroidal conformations are global minimizers of the proposed energy.  This finding is in agreement with experimental works of DNA condensation. This model, however, does not provide an immediate approach to obtain the trajectory of the DNA molecule from the resulting vector field. We therefore extended this model to one that assumes cylindrical trajectories and that incorporates the bending and cholesteric terms and the measured separation between DNA fibers. Our model shows one state of planar, concentric not helical stable conformation and two stable helical states. Three of the four bacteriophages analyzed fall in the stable helical states. We implemented a third model where we explicitly incorporate the diffusion and effects of ions on DNA to the liquid crystal formulation of the DNA. This model was solved numerically using the Poisson-Nerst-Planck equations. The model predicts the distance between DNA fibers as well as the distribution ions as a function of Na+ and Mg++ concentrations.

A separate model was implemented to study the problem of the DNA packing reaction. During packing, the DNA molecule is pushed into the capsid by molecular motor. The motor is toroidal in shape, and the DNA is translocated through the inner cavity. Our model, combines the action of the motor and the dynamics of the DNA molecule inside the capsid as the DNA is being packaged. We implemented several possible motor actions (deterministic vs stochastic, with and without torsion and with and without revolution) and concluded that motors that add torsion to the DNA at the time of packing show a chiral organization of the genome.      

A number of other results, both analytical and numerical were obtained when using these  and topological methods to study DNA-protein interactions (as in recombinases), kinetoplast DNA and the packing of the yeast genome. New experimental methods, topological and microscopy, were also developed.  

Throughout the project, we were committed to training students and postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary research and disseminating their findings to the public. We contributed to the education of young researchers by training one postdoc, 15 undergraduates (7 women and 3 students from under-represented minorities), 7 graduate students (6 women and 3 students from under-represented minorities), and one postbac from under-represented background, providing them with hands-on research in computational and experimental aspects of the project. Members of our team presented their research to a variety of audiences and in various formats, including conferences, webinars, seminars and piublic lectures (including an interview with BBC CrowdScience). Results of the research are reported in 12 research papers, 2 undergraduate theses, 1 MS thesis and 2 PhD theses.
